text.p: World number 19 Tim Henman came perilously close to a second consecutive first-round loss before beating Spanish wild card entry Sergi Bruguera 6-3 4-6 6-4 in the European Community tennis championship on Tuesday.
The rising British player, who was knocked out by German qualifier Martin Sinner in the first round of last week's Dubai Open, made a fluent start.
He appeared to be heading for a smooth victory over former French Open winner Bruguera until his concentration wavered towards the end of the second set.
"I wasn't able to finish the job off and that's where I probably made life difficult for myself," Henman said.
He only recovered his poise midway through the final set and made a decisive service break in the ninth game with a scorching passing shot down the line.
He served out the match with an ace in the next game after just two hours.

"I was able to hang in there and got my opportunity in the third (set) and was able to hang on to it. I'm pleased to come through a match like that. I needed it," said Henman, who won his first professional title in Sydney last month.
Henman, 22, plays Swede Mikael Tillstrom in the second round in their first ever encounter.
Ukrainian Andrei Medvedev went down 7-6 6-2 to former Olympic champion Marc Rosset of Switzerland in another first round match after wasting a 5-2 lead in the first set.

"I didn't capitalise on the chances I had in the first set," said Medvedev, who rose to a career-high world ranking of four in 1994 before suffering wrist, back and shoulder injuries which prevented him from recapturing his best form.
"Once Rosset won the first set he got more confident and started playing some really good tennis," said Medvedev, who is now ranked 29th in the world.
The top four seeds, including Croatian Goran Ivanisevic and German Boris Becker, enter the fray on Wednesday.
